results.title: Sean and Joel
results.creator_credit: Ian Munro, Martyn Down, Sandra Richardson, Ian Monroe, Tom Manefield and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “I myself”.
Sean and Joel realise that their father has left home for good. He has remarried and the boys have stayed with their single mother. Their feelings about their new situation are revealed as they learn to adjust to the aftermath of parental separation.

results.title: Bet your life
results.creator_credit: Mike Woolveridge, Don Anderson, Barry Pierce, Tasmania Dept. of Labour and Industry and Tasmanian Film Corporation
results.brief_description:
A 1980 film that encourages safe practices for workers on construction sites. The film presents examples of common factors that lead to industrial accidents, in occupations including electricians, carpenters, metal workers and bricklayers. Opening with scenes of a funeral, and presenting dramatic sequences of each accident, the narrator introduces each character and the careless practices leading to mishaps, dangerous accidents and death.

Produced by the Tasmania Film Corporation for the Department of Labour and Industry.

The colour is faded throughout the film.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: You can't shift the blame
results.creator_credit: Mike Woolveridge, Jack Zalkalns, Barry Pierce, Tasmania Dept. of Labour and Industry and Tasmanian Film Corporation
results.brief_description:
This 1980 film focuses on safety practices for operating mobile cranes and warns against the main types of mishaps and accidents that can occur. The film dramatises the importance of maintenance; setting up on solid ground; load charts and labels; and the role of the ‘dogman’ who directs the operation of the crane from near the load. The voiceover’s tone is casual and familiar, with use of colloquial terms such as ‘galah’. The footage of worksites is introduced and interspersed with an interview with a department official, reflecting on the dangerous and fatal accidents that have occurred.

Produced by the Tasmanian Film Corporation for the Department of Labour and Industry.

The colour is faded throughout the film.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: Going bush
results.creator_credit: Mike Woolveridge, Barry Pierce, Anne Whitehead and Tasmanian Film Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Maps and Map Reading”.
If a bushwalking adventure is not to turn into some sort of nightmare then careful planning must be undertaken at the outset. Five bushwalkers plan all aspects of their four day walk before setting off into the wilderness. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Aboriginal culture
results.creator_credit: Norma Disher, Keith Gow, Jerome Levy and Link Films
results.brief_description: The legends of Wayamba the turtle and Bohra the kangaroo retold by animated sketches based on the motifs of aboriginal bark paintings. An introductory sequence shows something of the variety and skill in aboriginal decorative art. Narrated by Leonard Teale.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Norma Disher, Keith Gow, Jerome Levy and Link Films

results.title: Citizen Kane (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Robert Wise, Orson Welles and Mercury Productions
results.brief_description: A faceless journalist sets out to investigate the life of media magnate and failed politician Charles Foster Kane. He seeks to uncover the meaning of “rosebud”, Kane’s last utterance. In turn satire, tragedy and gothic comedy, Citizen Kane is a triumph of disjointed, non-linear narrative in which the form becomes the theme, an ironic reflection upon the success ethic and the crushing weight of materialism. In drawing upon the tradition of classical narrative, while at the same time violating some of the expectations in the viewer’s reception of such narrative, Welles ultimately assured “Citizen Kane” of its place as a watershed in modern cinema. Credits: script-Herman J. Mankiewicz, Orson Welles; music-Bernard Hermann; photography-Gregg Toland; editors-Robert Wise, Mark Robson. Cast includes: Orson Welles, Joseph Cotten, Agnes Moorehead, Dorothy Comingore, Ray Collins, Everett Sloane.

results.title: The Good oil
results.creator_credit: Wayne Le Clos, Keith Gow, Elisabeth Knight and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Law”.
A funny, true to life story about a group of residents and their conflict with a nearby factory management. The residents’ indignation over sleepless nights and spoiled washing has its funny moments but the way is opened for serious questions about our changing environment

results.title: Australia at school
results.creator_credit: Hugh Alexander, Geoffrey Collings and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: Shows a range of schools from small country towns through to high schools in Sydney, grades from kindergarten to last year of high school. “A film outlining Australia’s system of primary and secondary education”. Cinematography by Frank Bagnall.

results.title: You Just Don't Realise
results.creator_credit: Eyewitness News, Paul Saunders and Philippe de Montignie
results.brief_description: In Australia, where there is one vehicle for every three people, road accidents have reached epidemic proportions with 4,000 people dying each year. The trauma of the accidents themselves is only eclipsed by the trauma of the chain of events that follow. Highly graphic scenes of car accidents in this film make viewing unsuitable for sensitive people, and preview is strongly recommended

results.title: Hassles
results.creator_credit: Ross Simmons, Jason Ollivier, Robin Hughes and Film Australia
results.brief_description: One of three films as part of the National Drug Education Program which takes an in-depth view of drug addiction in the day-to-day lives of ordinary people. The central character is a teenage boy who found the courage to give up heavy marijuana smoking. His motive was simply the challenge itself, but the price of his success is rejection by his lifelong friends and associates who accuse him of simply substituting one source of stimulation for another. Photography by Dean Semler. (See also ‘Thirst’ [012683] and ‘All in the same boat’ [012758].)
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ross Simmons, Jason Ollivier, Robin Hughes and Film Australia
